reviewText:
I will not write a complete review, there are enough of those here. I will not rant, either. I have played the game and I like it; the complexity, micro-managing and pace are fine by me (except you either get declared war on by everybody immediately or nothing happens at all).

HOWEVER, I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this game for a very simple reason: It's incomplete, and thus borders on a SCAM; at the very least, it reflects poorly on BattleGoat's business ethics.

This game (main game and addon) was supposed to receive additional attention after release, adding several more features (including a fallout/radioactivity and an environmental impact system). The game did indeed receive several content updates and additional features but, sadly, BattleGoat abandoned the game before the addition and/or revision of several critical features, leaving the game with a stupid AI, pretty damn buggy and, worst of all, content incomplete (which shows - there are buildings, designs, research that are completely pointless because the corresponding parts of the game were never implemented).

I therefore recommend that you avoid this game (and other games from BattleGoat) at all cost. This game is basically a polished Alpha and if the devs couldn't be bothered to finish this game, even after people already bought it, they are not worth your attention. Business practices like that should not be condoned or supported, so think twice before you buy from them - There may very well be a better, finished game out there.



EDIT: Since one of the devs commented on this 'review' (and my full response doesn't fit in a single comment), I will add his statement and my response to it to the 'review' itself.

chrisahl [developer] wrote:
Many statements in this review are completely false. The game received multiple updates for approximately 18 months after release of the core game including the life cycle of the expansion pack. The game is no buggy
date:
it is one of the most stable titles on the market. I'll hold it up to anything else out there. Features such as radioactive fallout where never promised and many never promised features were added. The content was also completed with multiple campaigns and scenarios. The tech tree is complete containing hundreds of technologies to research. Unit designs are all buildable and as usable as their specs warrant."



I don't know what game you're talking about

voteText: and there are few games that have crashed so often on me as this one (which is why I eventually stopped playing when you guys announced that you were moving on - it got to the point where it was simply not enjoyable because the game became more unstable [and lost a lot of performance] as the world progressed and units were built). And that happened pretty much in every session because
votesHelpful: you need an army to get stuff done. For what it sets out to do
votesTotal: the game is not nearly optimized enough - and that's not great but we can chalk that up to a lack of experience if we want to be nice about it.\nThat
commentsCount: does not apply to the crashes. Those are bugs (unless you want to call it a feature?) and gamebreaking bugs that are left in the game at the end of its lifecycle (which is technically not over since Steam allows you to still make some sales) are not exactly a sign of good business ethics.\n\nAs for fallout and environment: You can say they weren't "promised"

reviewText:
Supreme Ruler 2020 Gold is the combined product of Supreme Ruler 2020 and Global Crisis.
Produced by Battlegoat Studios and published by Paradox Interactive. (R1)
It is the child of the former *Supreme Ruler 2010 and It has expanded on the original game. (R2)

Note, please go to the bottom for a TLDR summary.

1. Introduction

There are 3 game modes.

● Campaign
● Sandbox
● Scenario

Campaign and sandbox are more or less the same.
If you have decided to play a campaign, you are presented with 3 campaigns to pick from World 2020, Global Crisis and Shattered World. (You can mod in more if you wish.)
Once you have selected your campaign you can chose from 182, 184, and 248, respectively.

You can play as the Superpower of the United States or the weakest of minor powers Malawi.
in World 2020 and Global Crisis.
Or
You can play as a state in the former United States or a sec of former Russia in Shattered World.
There are a lot of nations to choose from, just depends on how you wish to play.


Scenario, as its name implies, has a goal to complete within a given deadline.

Now you're given 3 main categories.

● Supreme Ruler 2020
● Global Crisis
● Custom Scenario

Each one has certain scenarios from their own time frame. Of course, Custom Scenario has only custom scenarios.

2. Gameplay

The gameplay is quite unique. I have yet to find a game that does a real-time strategy like this, it's nice.
Let's just say we are playing as South Carolina in the campaign Shattered World.

2.1 Interface

2.1.1 Top

At the top center of the screen we have the following; Treasury amount, nation played as, game menu, GPD/c, pause/play, game speed, time and date.

All of the above are just information except the time and game menu buttons.

2.1.2 Bottom

On the left corner/center of the screen, you have a sidebar with tabs of various areas.

● Land
● Production
● Research
● Finance
● State
● Operations
● Defense
● Unit Command

Once you have selected one of these the left center/corner will show you the tab and the information related to it.
Here you will have the option to change various sliders related to the tab you have selected. Or change the highlighted parts of the map.

On the right center/corner of the screen, you have your minimap and your email (notifications).

You will receive an email if there is anything of importance happening that the game thinks is important to you. You can change the settings for what you find important or not in the options menu.

2.2 Economy

As South Carolina we have to get a production of coal and metal ore. If we don't we will go into a huge deficit as we are import loads of resources to supply our factories. So we have to build some Metal ore/Coal mines till the demand is met.
But, if we are not careful at how many we build we will have to start importing industrial goods, which cost us more money.

That is just one aspect of the economy. Before we go to war, we have to make sure that we have the proper supply coverage is provided, the military goods produced to feed our solders, and the unit of solders themselves are trained.

It's rather detailed and I have only covered the most basic idea behind the economics behind the game.
I don't know the deepest secrets it offers as I have only played around 20 hours of the game.


2.3 Research/Technology

To be able to build a clean energy building or improve your coal power plants must be researched. Even the equipment your solders use and missiles your planes fire must first be researched as well. (Unless the nation you're playing as starts with the technology.)
Researching a technology is simple, it depends on the number of Research Centers you have and if you can afford to pay the employees.

Here is a small list of the main technologies you can research.

● Warfare
● Transportation
● Science
● Technology
● Medical
● Society

Each one is linked to the others in some way. Some are more beneficial than others. It's your job to find out which ones are better for your situation and goals than someone else.


There is also another type of research, Unit Design.

● Army (Ground)
● Naval (Sea bound)
● Air Force (flying units)
● Missiles (ammunition for missile for various land, air, and sea units)

All the categories above have multiple sub tabs in them for example the Army tab has,

● Infantry
● Recon
● Tanks
● Anti-Tank
● Artillery
● Air Defense
● Transport

With all these options you can tailor the Army/Navy/Air Force however you wish.

2.4 Warfare.

Warfare is very limited to how long your economy can support it. And how fast you will win/lose the war depends on the technology you have researched. It requires strong supply lines, some planning, and a bit of luck.

After you go to the State tab you can conduct negotiations with other nations, or just declare war.
Although, just being aggressive will make you get kicked out of the UN and other nations a valid casus belli.

Once you have a valid reason to go to war or you just declared it. You may now order your units to attack and cross the enemy’s borders and slowly moving your nation’s borders over the claimed territory. The map is made of small hexes so it is rather detailed on the terrain you can claim.

Each unit has a condition bar which shows you the state they are in and how much manpower they have. If the bar is red you are likely out of supplies. If it is almost empty the unit will soon be destroyed because of the lack of men in the unit.

Warfare is like Economics, it has some great details to it. I just cannot do justice explaining all of it.

3. Conclusion.

I enjoy the game very much. But, the only thing that I find to be a large drag is the fact time moves so slowly even on the highest speed setting. The highlight of the game is the complexity and details they made for us to conquer the world with.
This is a wonderful game I enjoy that is made by Battlegoat. It’s a great buy, especially for any real-time grand strategy game fans.

4. My Game Scores and Reasons behind them. TLDR; Look here.

Gameplay                7/10
The game play is amazingly depth. Before you can even think about going to war you must first stablise your economy, have a surplus income, and research and produce the units to attack. I believe that this game delivers the Conquer the world or die trying" idea really well.

Music/Sounds           4/10
Sounds are nice
date: they go well with it. They just get repetitive after a while of playing. Just like most other games of this category. Music as well
recommended:
but that can be fixed with anything you want it to be thanks audio players!

Creativity                 8/10
A nice and original idea to the real-time grand strategy games are. The creative depth and research that was put into the game was amazing.

Graphics                   5/10
Okay graphics for a game made in 2008. I suppose if they were much better than they are most computers at that time couldn't handle all the calculations the computer has to make.

Replay Value            6/10
The replay value of this game is really dependent on the player
hoursPlayed: for me it's a good bit. But it's still dependent on my ability to set a goal. So it will be yours as well
voteText:
as I cannot set goals for you.

Enjoyment               8/10
I enjoy this game and I can see myself coming back to it at least for a hour or 2 each week. Who knows
helpfulPercent:
might even play it for a few hundred hours.

Overall                      6/10
This game has a lot of potential that is only limited to the players' want to conquer the world and how you want to do it. Diplomacy
votesFunny: but at the end of the day

reviewText: Honestly, this is a great game for people who really love strategy games. It goes so insanely deep with you having control over every little thing, and it's just astonishing how much you can really do. Scenarios, diplomacy, products your empire carries, imports/exports, and what's great is that most of that you don't even have to keep doing yourself, because your advisors can take care of most of it (With some guidance, of course. Don't make that economic advisor bond your nation to debt now...) And with how much you can do in the military! It's great being able to micromanage everything. Plus, it's real-time, and all the wars happen at once. There's no turns like in the other games like Civ, and you can really do a lot at once. And, if you really love global RTS, you get all the nations, plus some scenarios to make the world even more varied than before, like a Shattered world" map. If you don't want to take the time to learn it
date: then of course you'll hate it. But once you get it
recommended: it's a load of fun every time you play it."

reviewText: An impressive game with it's scale, it's rather difficult at first, the learning curve is steep if your coming from a Sid Meir game, but once you get the hang of it, your better prepared for trying your hand at Victoria 2. Unlike Victoria 2, the ultimate goal of this game is world conquest, that is your goal, but don't just invade countries willy nilly now, that's rather stupid. You have to take it slow and plan far ahead, that's what I like about this game, not to mention the research and trade systems. Seriously, have you ever sent the United States 1,100,000 barrels of oil in exchange for top notch military designs? Seriously oil is worth more then money in this game, the game is somewhat predictable, if your Russia and playing the Global Crisis scenario, China will usually invade you, but things can happen differently, depending on factors such as your military production, because a nation can become rather hostile to you out of fear of your military, it's a very indepth, somewhat complex, but yet surprisingly easy to learn, rousing goodtime of a Grand Strategt RTS.

reviewText:
Haven't played it much; but it has something I've always wanted from a Grand Strategy game! The ability to play as Alaska! I know it sounds odd, yet its always been a fantasty of mine that I have only lived out in Victoria II.

Supreme Ruler 2020 is at first a little hard to pick up, but this title is probally my favorite from the series solely due to the Shattered World campain, where all small states become independant counties. In short; its awesome! You can build up your empire from scratch!

Once I play it a little more, i'll write a review. But the first impression is good!

(Oh yeah, you can also play as yourself by adding your picture into the game :3 its cool, I got dressed up in my old BDU's and wore a beret to look intimidating)

reviewText:
I know it says I've played 250+ hours of this game, and I've certainly played quite a few, but probably half of that is letting the game run on its own while I was asleep, or having fallen asleep playing it.

The concept behind the game is really great, and I wish it had been implemented in a way that made it fun to play, but it wasn't.

I did play the original (SR2010) and it is certainly an improvement over that version - less buggy, better controls. But the core problems with the franchise remain.

Basic gameplay is excruciatingly slow; the fastest speed is a tenth of where it should be. Virtually every game mechanic is completely opaque, and zero effort is made to explain any of it. The economic model is absurd and way too easily exploited - even playing as Malawi (the poorest, most technologically backwards country in the world)  I can turn it into an economic powerhouse in just a few game years.

Since no effort is made to balance the various countries, conflicts are rather pointless. The AI is terrible no matter how difficult you make the settings. You have to make your own game objectives because the game itself has none.

Then there's the engineers" problem - if you lack the tech to build a really good infantry unit
date: engineers are a very strong infantry unit that can be built with no tech. Although very oddly you can't actually research the unit
recommended: you need to trade for the design - but anyone will trade it to you for some cash. The engineer has massive advantages - it's cheap
voteText: it can bridge terrain for other units
helpfulPercent: it can accelerate production and repair of buildings
votesHelpful: and it can beat the tar out of far more advanced units without breaking a sweat. Why a zero-tech engineer can pound the hell out of many types of advanced infantry units is beyond me.\n\nThe economy and force distributions aren't the only wildly imbalanced aspects to the game. Research is ridiculous - if you have the cash you can buy and use techs way way way beyond your tech level. Diplomacy is virtually pointless
votesTotal: as is any other form of non-warfare interaction with other countries.\n\nThe UN mechanic is also dubious
votesFunny: there are no substantial benefits to being a part of the UN
commentsCount: and a significant economic penalty is attached to being good by them
column16: when it should be the other way around. It's to your advantage to purposely get kicked out
column17: so that you don't have to pay their escalating membership fees - for which you get nothing in return. An example of how trying to stay good by the UN hurts you: it's apparently perfectly acceptable for a neighboring country with whom you are not at war to allow passage of enemy units to attack your territory
column18: but if you attack that neighbor for that act of war the UN will despise you for it.\n\nYour advisors are just as bad as the AI elsewhere; if you trust them to do anything they will mess it up badly. There's a system of implementing priorities for them
column19: but if this has any actually effect on their behavior I haven't been able to detect it.\n\nThe only thing this game does well
column21: is tactical unit management on the hex map. If you can slog through all the opaque mechanics and the gruelingly long setup time before a typical country can start invading others
column22: that part is reasonably satisfying.\n\nOther mechanics
column24: are just stupid and appear to directly contradict the "realism" goal of the game. Either eliminate that mechanic
column25: or do it properly!\n\nLike its predecessor
column26: SR2020 is a great idea that doesn't really work well as implemented."

reviewText:
So...this game is really good actually...here is what happened on my most recent playthrough I started:

Started the game off as Germany in 2020 Sandbox.
Got a few reserves ready scattered a little around Berlin and Munich and a little around the Western borders.
Deployed 3 Tornado jets ready with missiles in Kiel.
Played for 9 days in-game (Like 15 mins), it is now the 9th of January 2020, and I have made an alliance with Poland, France, UK and USA.
But as soon as the 9th of January actually came along, I that Belarussian forces were entering Poland with T-72s and Grad Rockets.
So, a week later (10 mins), I sent 5 Eurofighter Typhoons escorting 3 Tornado attack jets fitted with missiles ready to launch to Warsaw.
2 of my Eurofighters were shot down before they destroyed a coloum of 4 T-72s, which was a distraction as my other Eurofighters escorted my 3 Tornados to the southern border with Poland, where they blew up a town killing 10,000 civilians before returning to the allied airbase in Warsaw.
By now, it's the 16th of January, and I have around 20 units of A1 Leopard tanks fighting a few kilometres East of Warsaw, as I see Ukrainian T-72s and numerous BTRs enter the Belarus southern border.
As 4 villages are instantly lost to the advancing Ukrainians, I send in 2 units of Artillery to bombard a town nearby the Ukrainian forces.
A day after, I enter into an alliance with Ukraine, sending 30 units of several types of BTRs to reinforce the Ukrainian advance which is now sieging the enemy capital.
But the attack is repelled as 3 nukes hit ares around Kiev!
As soon as the nukes land, I see numerous tanks and other war vechicles from the small Russian area just North of Poland advancing south heading straight to Warsaw!
So now, I get really annoyed, and send 20 carpet bombers all the way from Berlin to bomb 3 towns in that Russian area with several missiles, killing 80,000 innocent Russian people.
As the war rages on, I end up sending another 50 units of A1 Leopards into Belarus, taking their capital, and fighting the Russian frontline as UK enters the war on my side, attacking Leningrad with paratroopers.

So far so good, and guess what...it's only the 1st of February! I love this game!

960/376 would nuke Moscow again

reviewText: Probably the most underappreciated grand strategy games of all time, largely due to the relatively rudimentary graphics. But make no mistake, this game has a level of strategic depth that will melt your face! Also one of the best national economic simulators ever. If you like grand strategy, economics, and/or war, then you owe it to yourself to get this game. Beware though, it is not for the faint of heart. No one has ever just jumped into this game and said, Oh yeah
date: I totally understand how this game works." I probably logged 50 hours before I truly had a grasp of the core mechanics
recommended: and then only with the assistance of a lot of online research/forum reading... TOTALLY WORTH IT!"

reviewText:
First of all, please, do not be fooled by my low play time - I bought the game quite some time ago and have played it for hundreds of hours. And I am long standing fan of the series, starting SR2010, now playing SR1936.

To sum it up, my recommendation is positive, but, please, read more as there are few objections and e.g. Bjoern has quite a few valid points. I would not recommend this game to just anyone.

The game is very ambitious, wide in scope and quite complex with sharp learning curve. Of course you can assign some tasks to AI, but why let computer play my game? Especially as decisions of AI advisors are often quite poor. In general, game more or less delivers what it promises - choose any country and run it as you wish in global environment.

However, there is quite a feel of unfinisheness in some aeas. I think the scope of project was too wide to deliver within set  budget and timeframe. Quite a few ideas are implemented only partially or got axed in full (NBC, environment, tourism and business centers... )

Now, to cover aspects of the game:

Research: there are several hundreds of technlogies and units in technology tree, but their effect is very often research and forget" without any significant effect. Still
date: quite a few technologis do have very visible effect. As for the units
recommended: you can do well enough with lets say 7 units for most of the game (see warfare). Researching hundreds of unit models covered in game is marginally interesting. Tech level is a bit strange concept - it is possible to have tech level of year 1990 and run phaser hover  tanks...\n\nDiplomacy is quite strange (but I fail to recall any 4X game with really working diplomacy model
hoursPlayed: and I played many of them - Galciv probably got closest). E.g. casus belli is mostly based on active unit production capacity which gives way to many exploits (as AI is unable to control this aspect)
voteText: but you will always face up "all computer coalition" in the end. However
helpfulPercent: I find diplomacy no better or worse than in any 4X game.\n\nEconomy is based (I believe) on Joseph Stiglitz theories. General idea is the more government spends
votesHelpful: the better economy performs. Economy view aside
votesTotal: this leads to not very realistic in game strategies and exploits. It is very easy to start as - e.g. - Madagascar and triple GDP/c in a year. Moreover
votesFunny: there is very nasty bug related to price mechanism which I will cover later. I do feel economy to be somewhat ovrsimplified
column16: I am economy geek :) ).\n\nWarfare is acceptable. Building few hundreds of APC (preferably laser ones) and several naval transports is enough to conquer the world. Everything else is just nice to have. Long range AA and fighters helps limit APC loses against air powers
column17: few dozens of stealth srategy bombers (B-2) are great to override entranched aeas. I found very limited use for tanks
column21: range AA and most of the aircrafts... There is just no real need to build these types of units. AI does its job to provide resistence
column22: but is by no means real oponent.\n\nAs for the nasty

column25: if it the only input. If ANY country manages to create "closed circle" - like most of the oil produced in synth fuel plant
column26: most of the electricity (used in synth fuel plant) produced in oil power plant - prices will get out of any reasonable range. GDP skyrockets and after several weeks treasury of this country will get out of range which game can handle. This destroys world market and after another few weeks
column27: population gets out of control (not sure if by standard game mechanisms or the data just get overwritten). The game is not salveable in this state. There are workarounds (either conquer the country before it gets there - only handful of countires can get into this loop)
column28: or casually check the countries and if they start going this way

column30: with careful handling this bug can be used as exploit to get unlimited treasury. The most usual culprit is Moscow
column31: by the year 2029. IMHO this bug should not have escaped testing. Apart of this bug
column33: if resouce hungry.\n\nTo sum it up
column34: even as I highlighted some negatives
column35: my overall feeling of the game is positive and - as I bought it for 22 euros and now just added to my steam collection for 2.5 - one of the best values for a buck despite its flaws. I would not hesitate to recommend buy for any global 4X games fan

reviewText: Absolutely a great game, extremely in depth strategy that is difficult to master but feels so rewarding. If you buy this game prepare to grind through rough times before you understand the game, and be ready to watch plenty of barely helpful youtube videos to try to understand it all. It'll be hard but once it all clicks amazing things happen.\n\nProtip: Blitzkrieging only works a couple of times early in game. Once you get later in game you will need high level artillery and nukes so start researching and building them early. When you're ready build a wall of infantry and armor and place your artillery behind them and move up slowly while obliterating anything in your path. It took me 9 months (in game) of shelling Moscow to get it to fall. Have fun!

reviewText:
Supreme ruler 2020, how long have I been searching for a game like you...

The answer is about 3 or four years. So what is this super-duper game then?

You can take any country in the world (even Andorra, never even knew that existed, its between France and Spain) and command it economically and politcally and militarily. But the best thing is that for once IT IS SET IN THE PRESENT, which makes it more intriguing. No longer are there obvious antagonist states such as Japan Germany or the USSR. You have to make them powerful. Obviously there is North Korea, absoloutely a must play. and China and Russia who are fun to play as. The real excitment lies in playing as Britain or France and attacking europe.

Graphically it is incredibly intense, maybe not in the same way as battlefield (the water is terrible), but displaying litterally TENS OF  THOUSANDS  of units can destroy your computer.

You can also play with real life military units. They are much better than some games (the sort that have light medium and heavy tanks) in that you can take american aircraft carriers and Russian tanks and then throw them into battle so it is one enormous, accurate, set of toy soldiers.

What could be better?

reviewText: Pretty Good War Game

reviewText: Supreme Ruler 2020 is a grand strategy game- what that means is that you get to take control of any country in the world and lead them to global dominance. (Or local dominance if you don't want to get sucked up in a really long match.) The challenge in the game is turning your nation into the best by correcting a faltering economy, and by creating an army that no other can hope to challenge. I used to recommend not getting this on Steam, but there's absolutely no reason to avoid getting it on Steam since it was updated! It's good fun if you're up for a reasonably simple but in-depth experience at trying your hand at playing a modern nation... or if you're feeling nationalistic, one of the split-off parts of a larger country. I personally love taking Oregon and conquering the American Northwest.

reviewText:
Supreme Ruler 2020 is a great game.
At first, I did not understand much of it, but I got a friend to help me out and now I am loving it!
Only downside about it is that whenever you play as a big nation and send a lot of troops to fight, your game freezes from time to time, which kind of sucks but otherwise this game is great.

Edit: It only freezes in Multiplayer

Final Verdict: 7.5/10
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: ive been playing this for quite some time now. Since i am a fan of strategy games i decided to give this game a go and i am very glad i did! the AI is a bit weird at times though. when they declare war theyll start attacking, and when that force gets defeated, theyre done. no more invasion for them. that so far is the only downside ive seen. it has been pretty fun to take some random country, like Romania, and make them a new world superpower and empire! the economy works great, unit supply is a little weird but still works, and the ministers are awesome when youre not yelling at them for sending your units in the middle of the sahara for no reason or crashing your economy. also half the time i play this it seems like they just send them away from the fight at half health, but oh well

reviewText: This game (and every other game in this series) seem to be a small view of the great things that could have come with this game. This game had the potential to be an extremely in-depth geopolitical grand strategy game. Instead, it is a hollow game about military conquest and making money, masked by a clutter of interface options all showing stats of little to absolutely no significance.\n\nThis game also feels as if the developers were currently working on a feature, and decided HEY! Lets add this!" and completely forgot about the task at hand
date: or could not be bothered to finish said task. A prime example would be the environment system. You may think
hoursPlayed: there is none!" and you would be mostly right
voteText: however with many Society technologies
helpfulPercent: they all have to do with the environment
votesHelpful: and some even have to do with nuclear fallout (another thing that is not to be seen). And some of the techs say
votesTotal: in the "effects" portion of the tech
commentsCount: why would they say it has these effects even though most of these techs dont do anything? Well
column16: the answer is simple. The developers were working on environmental effects to your actions and the actions of other nations
column17: and these technologies would help the global environmental situation. And by hints from the technology
column18: nuclear fallout would be an issue too. However
column19: the developers either did one of two things. They either thought "lets put this in
column21: and this" but never went back to the task at hand (as I said earlier) or had a hard time creating these systems (which I imagine would be complicated) and gave up completely. Not even bothering to remove the technologies that talk about environmental impact
column25: many (probably a majority) of the technologies have literally no impact. It is literally useless fluff put into the game and branded with a sign saying "THIS DOES SOMETHING" however
column27: I grant you there are also MANY technologies that do a lot
column28: however if you look at the grand strategy games put out by Paradox Interactive
column29: every single technology has a large impact and is essential.\n\nAnd all in all
column30: this game is largely unfinished. The developers did update it years ago
column31: however they still left behind the game
column32: and left it very hollow indeed. They moved on to create THREE new titles
column34: but with a shiny new interface
column36: and a better AI (which is TERRIBLE in 2020

column40: using said unfinished features and leaving them in other titles (environmental impact "modifiers" still implemented in their SR titles to date). I would also rant about how they pulled Supreme Ruler Ultimate from Early Access and "releasing" it in an extremely unfinished state
column41: however I have a review on that game for you already.\n\nAll in all
column42: I would not reccoment anybody to support the bad practices Battlegoat has gone through with many times

reviewText: Very hard game only for the true strategy gamer. Supreme Ruler is a game that combines rts and board game type senerios with the best world map I have ever seen in a game. The way the game is set up is you choose a nation and begin conquest. Very impressive nation managing. Makes you believe your a real ruler of a nation with all the hardship and glory. Best played with freinds, not many online games but lan works fine plus you will not simply win a game in a day. The game also features hundreds of scenerios which my personal favorite shatterd world where everyone is thier own nation even the United States is split up into fifty countries. Make sure you look up a tutorial before giving up. I give it a 10/10

reviewText: This is a very underrated game. While it suffers from a difficult learning curve and can be slow as hell once the number of units increases, for long-term Grand Strategy addicts the degree of complexity this game provides is a sheer joy. It's also a few years old, and already some of the near future" features feel like the past
date: but this doesn't mar the game as much as increase the entertainment value.\n\nThis Gold edition also includes some really excellent mods that expand the game in many ways
recommended: including some very good tech tree mods that extend the potential time period by quite a way. The AI is competent enough to challenge the player; not terrifyingly good like AI War
hoursPlayed: but certainly able to keep up.\n\nAll told: an excellent game for fans of vast quantities of detail."

reviewText: Supreme Ruler 2020 is a great game for those out that are obsessed with strategy games. Because it is a little dated, the servers are not up anymore, but there is some software you and your friend can get for that problem! (And it's free.) So, should you get this game? YES.

reviewText:
Rating:  7/10

I strongly recommend to buy the newer Supreme Ruler:  Cold War over this

Pros:

*Supreme Ruler makes you the leader of a nation and for people who have played games like Age of Empires will find this much more complex, game features tax system along with social services and puts you in charge of your military, education, and healthcare spending and much more

*Game lets you research weapons like Nukes, powerful tanks, missiles to fight REAL WORLD countries today as any country you wish to play as

*You could play as Russia and make alliances with the former Soviet states and wage war against Europe and the U.S and take over the entire world, but will the United Nations and countries be happy and continue trading with you?

*Game lets you take controls of several units in Real-time and order them to launch a nuke on a city or perhaps ask you artilery to bombard a town where there is enemy garrison or even ask your jets bomb the enemies tanks to oblivion, its all up to you and your choices

*Play with Friends online to wage war against each other and see who could conquer the world or maybe ally with your friends and help each other's countries take over the world

Cons:

*Regardless of wether you have a beast P.C time in the game passes by slow and this is due to the engine, this is especially frustaring in Multiplayer where playing on the fastest speed can result in waiting for 2 minutes for a day to pass

*Graphics are not that good, but certainly not horrible, the newer Supreme Ruler:  Cold War has improved graphics when it comes to terrain

*For people who would like to play in a more real-life world it can be irritating, the problem is that it is routine for countries around the world to all ally with each other wether it be Jamaica and Iraq or Japan and Nigeria

*Playing online is not very simple, it involves having to get third party software like Hamachi or GamesRanger to play with your friend or anyone in fact

Ultimately get this game if you have an imagination and crave being able to be put in charge of a country in a real-life sandbox, but do not expect a Triple A game that runs smoothly and has stunning graphics, you have to have an interest or liking for complex grand strategy games

reviewText:
This game....is a complicated. As a vetern of the hearts of Iron series, i understand the art of managing the army, economy, and politics. However, in game you have help from the AI which can command certain aspects too complicated to manage just as no one man can run a nation single handidly...well not succesfully.
This game suffers from a few important issues:

1.) horrible allied AI
2.) advisors and ministers assigned to each area of goverment are not useful at all and do not help you
3.) Military operations are too difficult to launch as a large nation, Commanding units in this game is STRAIT FROM HELL!!!
4. the time is SOOOOO slow, it goes by the hour at its fastest.....thats way to slow
5.) Again the time.....takes way too much in game time for anything to happen
6.) nations declare war upon you way too early

reviewText: It's painfully slow to progress, It's a game you play in the background while playing a more involving game.  The tutorial explains very little and there isn't much in terms of a soundtrack, with me hearing the same 3 minute track of music looped throughout the game.  It's mainly a military blob-'em up sandbox game, with nations absorbing one another unless you switch Earth to Mahatma Ghandi volatility setting.  However, there is barely a diplomacy system, with the AI being very rigid and hating the player's guts if you do as much as sneeze at another nation.  It just seems like an alpha game, I want to like it but it's so buggy and a chore to play.
